pulltitle: declare_namespace in __init__.py
pullsbody:
I was just running the instructions at https://github.com/mozilla/minion#setting-up-a-development-environment and was hitting this failure:

```
running develop
running egg_info
creating minion.frontend.egg-info
writing requirements to minion.frontend.egg-info/requires.txt
writing minion.frontend.egg-info/PKG-INFO
writing namespace_packages to minion.frontend.egg-info/namespace_packages.txt
writing top-level names to minion.frontend.egg-info/top_level.txt
writing dependency_links to minion.frontend.egg-info/dependency_links.txt
writing manifest file 'minion.frontend.egg-info/SOURCES.txt'
error: Namespace package problem: minion is a namespace package, but its
__init__.py does not call declare_namespace()! Please fix it.
(See the setuptools manual under "Namespace Packages" for details.)
```

So, I believe this PR is what is missing from `minion-frontend`.
pull_commit_message: declare_namespace

pulltitle: Fixed #109. Dashboard has a <select> to choose which group to view.
pullsbody:
First, this commit requires https://github.com/mozilla/minion-backend/issues/215
to be fixed and commits to be pulled in.

This commit has several important changes:

**HomeController is rewritten**
I have a problem with the original code. I need to save the promise
to be able to kill in-progress $timeout. Once I factored out I also
experienced multiple requests were fired concurrently. I believe
this issue would have been fixed by applying the fix below, but
since I already rewrote I am not going to bother verify my theory.

**Remove controller from $routeProvider's when(..)**
In `minion-main.js` we specify some routes and for each when(..)
case we specify the controller. I started out with a new controller
called `Ctrl` and then once the new controller was completed,
I changed it back to `HomeController`. I then noticed two
requests were made. My theory was the controller was called twice
and I was right. I reduced to a single index.html and a single
controller. A quick googling yield https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/angular/pXQrhrL84Xc
.

The fix is to remove controller from the when().

**Add a "Loading data.... cloak**
When we move away from one group to another there is a 2.5 second of wait time,
I introduced a simple "Loading data" visual (demo: just look at how
http://plnkr.co/ did it).

**Allow group selection in the dashboard view**
This is the original task of this ticket.

**Thoughts**
This ticket took me a long time. A total of two days of efforts to find all kinds of
problems in how we use angularJS. I am hoping in the upcoming weeks I can
improve my angularJS skill.
pull_commit_message:
Fixed #93. Send login once invite is accepted to get last_login date.

This fix might seem a waste for making a round trip. Well, the backend's
update_invite is monster and should be refactored to individual functions
to update both invite and user document. That being said, it isn't that
bad to make an extra round trip. It is a quick fix and actually does
reuse what has been implemented (login function in the frontend views
module).

pulltitle: Cleanup templates by centralizing nav context creation.
pullsbody:
Initially looked into the low hanging fruit of Issue #86, but
decided it makes sense to do some refactoring here, to make the templates more
DRY, and provide sanity moving forward. Primary adjustments are:
- Compile all routes into an app.navItems variable
- Introduce app.navContext, allowing us to easily get the navigation
  items for a specific "section" of the site
- Adjust the controller to contain more variables that are useful
  in rendering a nav.

I am completely new to AngularJS, infact -- this is the first time I ever
touched it! So, there are some issues. For example, in `AdminGroupController`
we need a sub nav for the "Group Editor". The implementation of adding
this to the nav feels very hackish and perhaps we can implement
some notion of sub navigation. However, this may not be required right now
given the simplicity of the admin, so perhaps it's ok for the current
implementation.

Either way, happy to hear your feedback on this, and what I can improve on before merge. :)
pull_commit_message:
Cleanup templates by centralizing nav context creation.

Initially looked into the low hanging fruit of Issue #86, but
decided it makes sense to do some refactoring here, to make the templates more
DRY, and provide sanity moving forward. Primary adjustments are:

* Compile all routes into an app.navItems variable
* Introduce app.navContext, allowing us to easily get the navigation
    items for a specific "section" of the site
* Adjust the controller to contain more variables that are useful
    in rendering a nav.

I am completely new to AngularJS, infact -- this is the first time I ever
touched it! So, there are some issues. For example, in `AdminGroupController`
we need a sub nav for the "Group Editor". The implementation of adding
this to the nav feels very hackish and perhaps we can implement
some notion of sub navigation. However, this may not be required right now
given the simplicity of the admin, so perhaps it's ok for the current
implementation.

pulltitle: Fixed #93. Send login once invite is accepted to get last_login date.
pullsbody:
This fix might seem a waste for making a round trip. Well, the backend's
update_invite is monster and should be refactored to individual functions
to update both invite and user document. That being said, it isn't that
bad to make an extra round trip. It is a quick fix and actually does
reuse what has been implemented (login function in the frontend views
module).
pull_commit_message:
Fixed #93. Send login once invite is accepted to get last_login date.

This fix might seem a waste for making a round trip. Well, the backend's
update_invite is monster and should be refactored to individual functions
to update both invite and user document. That being said, it isn't that
bad to make an extra round trip. It is a quick fix and actually does
reuse what has been implemented (login function in the frontend views
module).

pulltitle: Fixed #66. If scan hasn't started, show '---' instead of 44 years ago or...
pullsbody:
... never.

Never as a default value sounds weird, so I proposed the switch to '---'.
Since the original implementation append a time elapse filter with ()
in the template, to make use of the changes in the filter
`scan_datetime` without hardcoding the `()` in the Javascript (that's a
presentation logic), I use `ng-show`.
pull_commit_message:
Fixed #66. If scan hasn't started, show '---' instead of 44 years ago or never.

Never as a default value sounds weird, so I proposed the switch to '---'.
Since the original implementation append a time elapse filter with ()
in the template, to make use of the changes in the filter
``scan_datetime`` without hardcoding the ``()`` in the Javascript (that's a
presentation logic), I use ``ng-show``.

pulltitle: Added support for invite confirmation. Fixed invite url.
pullsbody: We have to pull out the signIn() function from `LoginController` or duplicate it. We chose to pull it out to avoid small duplication. A great lesson to learn is unless you have called a particular controller, the controller is not executed and thus its methods will not be available.

pulltitle: Added requires_session decorator to check session. See #12
pullsbody: In the latest commit, I have enhanced the decorator to comply with the expectation.
pull_commit_message:
Enhanced @requires_session decorator. See #12.

This commit improves the previous design and is aligned with the issue's
expectation. The previous commit provided some basic framework for
building this one.

What remains to be done is testing the front-end system. We probably can
use requests by utilizing requests.session class to establish session.
At some point it might be more convinent if we write front-end tests
using tools like Seleium.
